title: How to know if a YouTube video is copyrighted - Quora

response.answer_text: If it’s in video form and not just in somebody’s head, it’s copyrighted unless the person who created it specifically released it into the public domain. You should always assume that ANY video or creative work you find online anywhere (not just on YouTube) is copyrighted. After all, if you didn’t produce it yourself, then somebody else did, and unless that person specifically released it into the public domain or makes clear that it is not copyrighted, then it’s only safe to assume that it is until and unless you can confirm otherwise. It used to be a requirement that the owner register the copyright or include specific copyright notations (like the words “Copyright” or the symbol ©), but those are no longer required, and the entire history of YouTube has come about since long after that changed. In fact, any work produced after 1976 automatically bears a copyright the moment it was “fixed in tangible form” (i.e., no longer in somebody’s head but recorded in some way so as to be perceptible or recognizable).[1] A video posted online certainly counts as a tangible medium of expression. If you want to use someone else’s video, contact them to request their permission. One major advantage with YouTube is that it is such a large and supportive community, and often people post their works there because they want to share them with others. So the chances are often good that if you ask, the producer may be willing to grant permission (assuming it’s actually their work*). *Lots of material on YouTube wasn’t uploaded legally, or it may include content that the original producer had permission to include but you wouldn’t, so that’s why it’s important to ask. NOTE: While I have stated and referenced the principles and definitions as they are articulated in the United States’ copyright law, the Berne Convention makes them applicable in all 170+ countries which are signatories.[2] However, since YouTube is based in the U.S., its laws apply. Footnotes[1] https://www.copyright.gov/circs/circ01.pdf[2] Countries Berne Convention

It is pretty easy to tell if a video is not protected by copyright. It will be a silent film in black and white. Copyrights last a LONG time. For works created before the newer standard of Life + 50 years (Life + 70 in some countries, like the U.S.) the standard was 95 years. “Talkies” were introduced in 1927 (The Jazz Singer - Wikipedia). Sure, technically a movie made in the U.S. before 1977 needed to have its copyright registered and then renewed. The instances of a production company failing this are small enough to count on two hands. (How a Copyright Mistake Created the Modern Zombie - Plagiarism Today) So really, for practical purposes your question just isn’t meaningful. Essentially all of the content on YouTube is protected by copyright. Because copyright is an automatic process these days, lasting for generations.
